question: If pumice forms when lava cools, what type of rock is pumice?

content.source_1: Igneous rocks form when molten rock (magma or lava) cools and solidifies.
content.source_2: Pumice forms when gas-rich volcanic lava is explosively ejected and rapidly cools, trapping bubbles and creating a highly vesicular rock.
content.source_3: Many sedimentary rocks (e.g., sandstones and some limestones) display abundant porosity, with numerous visible pore spaces between grains.
content.source_4: Pumice is extremely porous and low in density; fresh pieces often float on water because of their abundant vesicles.
content.source_5: In field identification, visible porosity is often used as a practical clue suggesting a sedimentary rock, whereas igneous rocks typically show dense, interlocking crystalline textures.
content.source_6: Metamorphic rocks form when existing rocks are transformed by heat and pressure without melting; they do not originate directly from cooled lava.
